 Apache Jmeter

Apache Jmeter is open source software, a 100% pure Java application designed to load test functional behavior and measure performance. It was originally designed for testing Web Applications but has since expanded to other test functions. Apache JMeter may be used to test performance both on static and dynamic resources (Webservices (SOAP/REST), Web dynamic languages - PHP, Java, ASP.NET, Files, etc. -, Java Objects, Data Bases and Queries, FTP Servers and more). It can be used to simulate a heavy load on a server, group of servers, network or object to test its strength or to analyze overall performance under different load types. You can use it to make a graphical analysis of performance or to test your server/script/object behavior under heavy concurrent load.



1 - Requirements

  • Apache jmeter => 2.13
  • 1GHz or higher 32-bit or 64-bit Intel or AMD64 processor.
  • 1GB of RAM
  • 240MB of hard disk space for installation.
  • Windows, Ubuntu, Red Hat, Fedora, CentOS, Suse; or other distributions.
  • Java => 6
  • Standar and extra set plugins.
  • Mysql and Oracle jbmc



2 - Downloads
Apache Jmeter Repository Source
Standar Plugin Repository Source
Extra Plugins Repository Source
Mysql Jdbc Repository Source
Oracle Jdbc Repository Source
Ssh Plugin Repository Source
Example test Repository Source



3 - Installation

  • Download Jmeter from the repository.
  • Unzip Jmeter in a place of preference like C:\Jmeter or usr/local/Jmeter
  • Now you can run jmeter go to Jmeter\bin\ and run jmeterw.cmd or jmeter.sh according to your OS



3.1 - Plugins & Extras

Now we need this plugins to set external properties, see correctly json, xml formats, connect to ssh and database.

Standar and extra plugins installation

  • Extract archive contents to JMeter/lib/ext.
  • Restart JMeter to load new plugins.

JDBC Installation

  • Extract archive contents to JMeter/lib
  • Restart JMeter to load new plugins.

Ssh Plugin

  • Extract archive contents to JMeter/lib
  • Restart JMeter to load new plugins.



3.2 - Set external properties

Relative path

This is requiered to create a external properties in the project folder.

  • First we need create a user defined variables Addd > Config element and click User defined variables
  • Now go to add two variables configuration=${__BeanShell(import org.apache.jmeter.services.FileServer; FileServer.getFileServer().getBaseDir();)} and bar=${__BeanShell(File.separator,)}
  • To set the path create Add > Config element and click in Variables from csv file
  • Now define the path, we create two variables to do this, why? because the diferences between windows and linux in the path “" & “/”. The variable name is bar, the other variable is to set the folder of the project configuration. Write the path on CSV File input and = in Separator input:


Example:

  • ${configuration}${bar}config${bar}host.conf

This is equal to:

  • linux: /config/ host.conf
  • Windows: \config\ host.conf
  • The last step is create the properties file, by default in my_project/config/host.conf and contains:


Example:

# Configuracion host y usuario sso

host=172.16.0.90
user=admin
pass=admin
port=80



3.3 - Database Configuration

  • First we need to create the jdbc in jmeter Add > Config Element > JDBC Connection Configuration
  • Now modify Variable name like mysql or oracle as appropriate.
  • The last step is modify Database Connection Configuration :

Mysql

  1. Databae URL: jdbc:mysql://${ruta_database}:3306/${nombre_base}
  2. JDBC Driver class: com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
  3. Username: ${user_database}
  4. Password: ${password_database}

Oracle

  1. Databae URL: jdbc:oracle:thin:@${ruta_database}:1521:ORCL
  2. JDBC Driver class: oracle.jdbc.driver.OracleDriver
  3. Username: ${user_database}
  4. Password: ${password_database}

5 - Extras

Shortcuts

  • Disable/Enable = CTRL + T
  • Run suite = CTRL + R
  • Clean results = CTRL + E
  • Seach in the Suite test = CTRL + F
  • Open tree = →
  • Close tree = ←
  • Stop Test : CTRL + .
  • Shutdown Test : CTRL + ,
